user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_destroy_response:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN void
MHD_destroy_response (struct MHD_Response *response)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *pos;

  if (NULL == response)
    return;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
  if (0 != --(response->reference_count))
  {
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
    MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
    return;
  }
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
  MHD_mutex_destroy_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
  if (NULL != response->crfc)
    response->crfc (response->crc_cls);

  if (NULL != response->data_iov)
  {
    free (response->data_iov);
  }

  while (NULL != response->first_header)
  {
    pos = response->first_header;
    response->first_header = pos->next;
    free (pos->header);
    free (pos->value);
    free (pos);
  }
  free (response);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I selected all code fragments that perform the function's cleanup (mutex unlock/destroy, callback invocation, freeing data_iov, freeing header list, final free). These fragments are the parts that can become unreachable at runtime depending on the early return taken after decrementing response->reference_count, and therefore should be investigated for possible unreachable-code issues or logic errors across build configurations. Other fragments in the function were not included because they are simple, directly reachable control or checks: the initial NULL check (if (NULL == response) return;) is an immediate, valid guard; the initial mutex lock (MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&response->mutex);) and the reference-count decrement and test (if (0 != --(response->reference_count))) are the controlling operations that determine reachability of the cleanup code and are intentionally present; there is no other code in the function that is statically impossible to reach independent of runtime state or build-time macros. Therefore only the cleanup blocks listed above warrant further investigation for potential violations of MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.
